author: sky.cactus
content: <@364458974906548225> I would like to push back a little bit on your claim that a stateless client today wouldn't be valuable on its own.  I tentatively argue that if we were to build a stateless client of the form we have been talking about, people would still need infrastructure providers like Infura but they would no longer need to *trust* those infrastructure providers.  A user could run a small stateless client (potentially even in their browser) and point that at some infrastructure as a service provider like Infura for data access.  They would not need to trust that the data from this provider is accurate because as a stateless client they would be able to validate all proofs provided by that infrastructure provider.

author: sky.cactus
content: As an example, if someone wants to do an `eth_call`, the stateless client would ask the backing infrastructure provider for a proof of the `eth_call`, but that proof could be fully validated by the stateless client in-memory.

author: sky.cactus
content: While this seems like a minor thing, it has potential to allow people to use completely untrusted infrastructure providers. We could potentially create a network of infrastructure providers (maybe even discoverable via P2P network in the light clients) that stateless clients can connect to.

author: sky.cactus
content: This to me feels like a big win over the status quo, even if we never are able to achieve a fully stateless world like you are imagining.

author: sky.cactus
content: Perhaps I'm missing something about the levels of trust required for a stateless client, or my analysis of the utility of an IaaS backed stateless client is incorrect?

author: pipermerriam
content:
(just to write it out, not to argue as it seems we're not in any real disagreement)
The larger solution:

- fixes the un-enforceable assumption that all clients have the chain history via the chain history network, allowing existing clients to clear out almost 200GB of HDD footprint.
- fixes the un-enforceable assumption that all clients hold the full state, allowing things like stateless clients and UX improvements like beam sync
- gives us actually light clients
- makes building full clients easier
- gives current clients more options for how they build their client functionality.  The client landscape might finally look meaningfully different afterwards
- gives us infrastructure that is well suited to support regenesis or other mechanisms that sweep active state into an official "cold" status.
 
I don't think doing this actually slows down any of the current stateless efforts.  It doesn't de-prioritize anything on the existing roadmap or suggest we slow down work on reducing witness sizes or enshrining witnesses in the protocol.
